title: Louis Page
text:
Louis Antonio Page (27 March 1899 – 11 October 1959) was an <a href="England%20national%20football%20team">England</a> international <a href="association%20football">football</a> player and football manager. His brothers <a href="Tom%20Page%20%28footballer%29">Tom</a>, <a href="Jack%20Page%20%28footballer%2C%20born%201886%29">Jack</a> and <a href="Willie%20Page">Willie</a> were also professional footballers.
He spent his youth with <a href="Everton%20F.C.">Everton</a> and <a href="South%20Liverpool%20F.C.">South Liverpool</a>, before beginning his professional career with <a href="Stoke%20City%20F.C.">Stoke</a> in 1919. After the "Potters" won promotion out of the <a href="Football%20League%20Second%20Division">Second Division</a>, he moved on to <a href="Northampton%20Town%20F.C.">Northampton Town</a> in 1922. Three years later he moved up to the <a href="Football%20League%20First%20Division">First Division</a> with <a href="Burnley%20F.C.">Burnley</a>. He scored 111 goals in 248 league games for the "Clarets", before he was sold to <a href="Manchester%20United%20F.C.">Manchester United</a> for a £1,000 fee in March 1932. Seven months later he moved on to <a href="Port%20Vale%20F.C.">Port Vale</a>, before ending his playing career in the <a href="English%20Football%20League">Football League</a> in summer 1933.
He started his management career with <a href="Yeovil%20Town%20F.C.">Yeovil & Petters United</a>, and led the club to the Southern League West Section and Western League Division 1 titles in 1934–35. He then returned to the Football League with <a href="Newport%20County%20A.F.C.">Newport County</a>. He later took charge at <a href="Glentoran%20F.C.">Glentoran</a>, before he was put in charge at <a href="Swindon%20Town%20F.C.">Swindon Town</a> following the conclusion of <a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a>. He spent eight years in charge of the <a href="Football%20League%20Third%20Division%20South">Third Division South</a> club, before he spent three years in charge at <a href="Chester%20City%20F.C.">Chester</a>, who were struggling at the foot of the <a href="Football%20League%20Third%20Division%20North">Third Division North</a> table.
Club career.
Page began his senior career with <a href="Merseyside">Merseyside</a> clubs <a href="Everton%20F.C.">Everton</a> and <a href="South%20Liverpool%20F.C.">South Liverpool</a>. He entered professional football with <a href="Stoke%20City%20F.C.">Stoke</a> during the <a href="1919%E2%80%9320%20Stoke%20F.C.%20season">1919–20</a> season, scoring his first senior goal on 13 December, in a 2–1 defeat to <a href="Birmingham%20City%20F.C.">Birmingham</a> at <a href="St%20Andrew%27s%20%28stadium%29">St Andrew's</a>. However, he featured just eight times in <a href="1920%E2%80%9321%20Stoke%20F.C.%20season">1920–21</a> and then once in <a href="1921%E2%80%9322%20Stoke%20F.C.%20season">1921–22</a>, as the "Potters" won promotion out of the <a href="Football%20League%20Second%20Division">Second Division</a>.
He left the <a href="Victoria%20Ground">Victoria Ground</a> to sign with <a href="Northampton%20Town%20F.C.">Northampton Town</a> of the <a href="Football%20League%20Third%20Division%20South">Third Division South</a>. The "Cobblers" finished eighth in <a href="1922%E2%80%9323%20Football%20League">1922–23</a> and <a href="1923%E2%80%9324%20Football%20League">1923–24</a>, and ninth in <a href="1924%E2%80%9325%20Football%20League">1924–25</a>. He scored 24 goals in 122 league games at the <a href="County%20Cricket%20Ground%2C%20Northampton">County Ground</a>.
Page transferred to <a href="Burnley%20F.C.">Burnley</a>, who finished one place and one point above the <a href="Football%20League%20First%20Division">First Division</a> relegation zone in <a href="1925%E2%80%9326%20Football%20League">1925–26</a>. He wrote himself into the <a href="List%20of%20Burnley%20F.C.%20records%20and%20statistics">club's record books</a> on 10 April 1926, when he scored six goals in a 7–1 win over Birmingham. He finished as the <a href="List%20of%20Burnley%20F.C.%20seasons">club's top scorer</a> in 1925–26 with 26 goals. He scored 15 goals in <a href="1926%E2%80%9327%20Football%20League">1926–27</a> to again become the club's top scorer, as the "Clarets" achieved a top five finish. They dropped to 19th in <a href="1927%E2%80%9328%20Football%20League">1927–28</a>, two places and one point above the relegation zone. They again finished 19th in <a href="1928%E2%80%9329%20Football%20League">1928–29</a>, but were this time seven points above the drop zone. Burnley were relegated in <a href="1929%E2%80%9330%20Football%20League">1929–30</a>, having attained a lower goal average than <a href="Sheffield%20United%20F.C.">Sheffield United</a>. They then finished eighth in the Second Division in <a href="1930%E2%80%9331%20Football%20League">1930–31</a> and 19th in <a href="1931%E2%80%9332%20Football%20League">1931–32</a>. He made 248 league appearances, scoring 111 goals, during his time at <a href="Turf%20Moor">Turf Moor</a>.
Page joined <a href="Walter%20Crickmer">Walter Crickmer</a>'s Second Division side <a href="Manchester%20United%20F.C.">Manchester United</a> for a £1,000 fee in March 1932. He played nine games at the end of the <a href="1931%E2%80%9332%20Manchester%20United%20F.C.%20season">1931–32</a> season and three games at the start of the <a href="1932%E2%80%9333%20Manchester%20United%20F.C.%20season">1932–33</a> season, before falling out of favour under new secretary <a href="Scott%20Duncan%20%28footballer%29">Scott Duncan</a> and moving on to league rivals <a href="Port%20Vale%20F.C.">Port Vale</a> in October 1932. He played 19 games in all competitions during the <a href="1932%E2%80%9333%20Port%20Vale%20F.C.%20season">1932–33</a> season, falling out of favour in March 1933. He was not kept on at <a href="The%20Old%20Recreation%20Ground">The Old Recreation Ground</a> beyond the campaign, and so Page left the <a href="English%20Football%20League">Football League</a> to forge a career in management.
International career.
Page featured for <a href="England%20national%20football%20team">England</a> seven times in 1927, alongside England and <a href="Everton%20F.C.">Everton</a> great <a href="Dixie%20Dean">Dixie Dean</a>. He played four <a href="British%20Home%20Championship">British Home Championship</a> games and three <a href="exhibition%20game">friendlies</a>, and scored against <a href="Belgium%20national%20football%20team">Belgium</a> on 1 May 1927; his goal came in the 63rd minute, in what was a 9–1 victory.
Management career.
Yeovil & Petters United.
Page's first managerial post was with <a href="Yeovil%20Town%20F.C.">Yeovil & Petters United</a> in summer 1933, also being registered as a player. He finished as the <a href="List%20of%20Yeovil%20Town%20F.C.%20seasons">club's top scorer</a> in <a href="1933%E2%80%9334%20Southern%20Football%20League">1933–34</a> with 23 goals. In the <a href="1934%E2%80%9335%20Southern%20Football%20League">1934–35</a> season, Yeovil topped both the Southern League West Section and Western League Division 1 tables.
Newport County.
Page was appointed manager at Welsh club <a href="Newport%20County%20A.F.C.">Newport County</a> in 1935. The club finished 21st in the 22 team <a href="Football%20League%20Third%20Division%20South">Third Division South</a> in <a href="1935%E2%80%9336%20Newport%20County%20A.F.C.%20season">1935–36</a>, but successfully applied for re-election. Newport then moved up to 19th in the <a href="1936%E2%80%9337%20Newport%20County%20A.F.C.%20season">1936–37</a> campaign, finishing two places and two points above the re-election zone. He left the club on 9 September 1937, a few games into the <a href="1937%E2%80%9338%20Newport%20County%20A.F.C.%20season">1937–38</a> season; his successor, <a href="Billy%20McCandless">Billy McCandless</a>, led the club to a 16th-place finish in the Third Division South.
After leaving Newport he became trainer-coach at <a href="Glentoran%20F.C.">Glentoran</a> in <a href="1939%E2%80%9340%20Irish%20League">1939–40</a>, as the "Glens" finished third in the <a href="IFA%20Premiership">Irish League</a>. He later served as manager of <a href="Liverpool">Liverpool</a>-based Carlton F.C.
Swindon Town.
When league football resumed after the <a href="Second%20World%20War">Second World War</a>, he was appointed manager of <a href="Swindon%20Town%20F.C.">Swindon Town</a>. Page was forced to build a completely fresh team, and so Swindon's fourth-place finish in the <a href="Football%20League%20Third%20Division%20South">Third Division South</a> in <a href="1946%E2%80%9347%20Football%20League">1946–47</a> was seen as a highly respectable achievement. The "Robins" slumped to 16th place the <a href="1947%E2%80%9348%20Football%20League">following season</a> – just two points off the bottom spot. They did though knock <a href="Burnley%20F.C.">Burnley</a> out of the <a href="FA%20Cup">FA Cup</a>, before being beaten in the Fifth Round by <a href="Southampton%20F.C.">Southampton</a>. In <a href="1948%E2%80%9349%20Football%20League">1948–49</a>, Swindon again finished fourth, without ever challenging for the <a href="promotion%20and%20relegation">promotion</a> spot.
Swindon then finished 14th in <a href="1949%E2%80%9350%20Football%20League">1949–50</a>, 17th in <a href="1950%E2%80%9351%20Football%20League">1950–51</a>, 16th in <a href="1951%E2%80%9352%20Football%20League">1951–52</a>, and 18th in <a href="1952%E2%80%9353%20Football%20League">1952–53</a>. Page always had to deal with a shoestring budget at the <a href="County%20Ground%2C%20Swindon">County Ground</a>, and was forced to sell many of his top players. Page was relieved of his duties at the end of the 1952–53 season, and was handed £500 in compensation.
Chester.
He became manager of <a href="Chester%20City%20F.C.">Chester</a> in 1953. The "Seals" finished bottom of the <a href="Football%20League%20Third%20Division%20North">Third Division North</a> in <a href="1953%E2%80%9354%20Football%20League">1953–54</a>. The <a href="Sealand%20Road">Sealand Road</a> outfit again finished last in <a href="1954%E2%80%9355%20Football%20League">1954–55</a>, before rising to 17th in <a href="1955%E2%80%9356%20Football%20League">1955–56</a>. He later worked as a <a href="Scout%20%28association%20football%29">scout</a> for <a href="Leicester%20City%20F.C.">Leicester City</a>.
Career statistics.
